title: How to Cook Salmon in a Pan

methods.name: Pinot Noir Poached Salmon with Herbs

steps.headline: Rinse the salmon filets with cold water and pat them dry.
steps.description: Combine the thyme, rosemary, salt, and pepper in a small bowl. Squeeze the lemon juice over each filet and then sprinkle on the seasoning.

steps.headline: Combine the wine and water in a frying pan or skillet that is at least 2 inches (5.1 cm) deep.
steps.description: Bring the mixture to a simmer and then reduce the heat to low.

steps.headline: Add the salmon filets in a single layer.
steps.description: Cover the pan and cook for 10-12 minutes, or until the salmon turns opaque. Place the filets skin-side down if the skin is still attached.

steps.headline: Transfer the salmon to a serving dish.
steps.description: Serve with a side of brown rice, asparagus, or green salad and garnish with fresh rosemary sprigs.

steps.headline: Rinse the salmon filets and pat them dry.
steps.description: Coat each piece of fish with a very thin layer of cornstarch. Shake the fish gently to brush off any excess cornstarch.

steps.headline: Heat the olive oil on a frying pan/skillet over medium-high heat.
steps.description: Add the salmon, skin-side down, to the pan. Sprinkle the top of the salmon with cajun seasoning, salt, and pepper and allow the bottom to cook about 1/3 of the way through.

steps.headline: Flip the salmon over with a spatula and cook the other side.
steps.description: Sprinkle the upward facing side with cajun seasoning, salt, and pepper and let the other side cook 1/3 of the way through.

steps.headline: Remove the fish from the pan and transfer it to a serving dish.
steps.description: Serve with a side of sautéed vegetables, green salad, or salsa. Garnish with cilantro if desired.

methods.name: Broiled Salmon with Herb and Mustard Sauce

steps.headline: Rinse the salmon filets and pat them dry.
Combine the garlic, rosemary, thyme, wine, oil, and mustard in a food processor.
steps.description: Grind the ingredients for about 30 seconds, or until a sauce is formed. Transfer the sauce to a small bowl.

steps.headline: Preheat the broiler compartment of your oven.
steps.description: Spray the ovenproof frying pan with non-stick cooking spray and place the filets skin-side down in a single layer. Alternatively, salmon filets can be cooked on a large rimmed baking pan.

steps.headline: Broil the filets for 2 minutes and then spoon on the mustard sauce.
steps.description: Cook for an additional 5 minutes, or until the filets are golden brown and cooked through.

steps.headline: Transfer the salmon to a serving dish.
steps.description: Garnish with lemon wedges and serve immediately.

text: Pinot Noir Poached Salmon with Herbs Rinse the salmon filets with cold water and pat them dry. Combine the thyme, rosemary, salt, and pepper in a small bowl. Squeeze the lemon juice over each filet and then sprinkle on the seasoning. Combine the wine and water in a frying pan or skillet that is at least 2 inches (5.1 cm) deep. Bring the mixture to a simmer and then reduce the heat to low. Add the salmon filets in a single layer. Cover the pan and cook for 10-12 minutes, or until the salmon turns opaque. Place the filets skin-side down if the skin is still attached. Transfer the salmon to a serving dish. Serve with a side of brown rice, asparagus, or green salad and garnish with fresh rosemary sprigs. Crispy Cajun Pan-Fried Salmon Rinse the salmon filets and pat them dry. Coat each piece of fish with a very thin layer of cornstarch. Shake the fish gently to brush off any excess cornstarch. Heat the olive oil on a frying pan/skillet over medium-high heat. Add the salmon, skin-side down, to the pan. Sprinkle the top of the salmon with cajun seasoning, salt, and pepper and allow the bottom to cook about 1/3 of the way through. Flip the salmon over with a spatula and cook the other side. Sprinkle the upward facing side with cajun seasoning, salt, and pepper and let the other side cook 1/3 of the way through. Remove the fish from the pan and transfer it to a serving dish. Serve with a side of sautéed vegetables, green salad, or salsa. Garnish with cilantro if desired. Broiled Salmon with Herb and Mustard Sauce Rinse the salmon filets and pat them dry. Set aside. Combine the garlic, rosemary, thyme, wine, oil, and mustard in a food processor. Grind the ingredients for about 30 seconds, or until a sauce is formed. Transfer the sauce to a small bowl. Preheat the broiler compartment of your oven. Spray the ovenproof frying pan with non-stick cooking spray and place the filets skin-side down in a single layer. Alternatively, salmon filets can be cooked on a large rimmed baking pan. Broil the filets for 2 minutes and then spoon on the mustard sauce. Cook for an additional 5 minutes, or until the filets are golden brown and cooked through. Transfer the salmon to a serving dish. Garnish with lemon wedges and serve immediately.
